TI: The hippocampal neurons of neuronal apoptosis inhibitory protein 1 (NAIP1)-deleted mice display increased vulnerability to kainic acid-induced injury.
AB: The neuronal apoptosis inhibitory protein (NAIP) is a member of a novel family of inhibitor of apoptosis (IAP) proteins. The IAP genes are highly conserved from baculovirus to metazoans and suppress apoptosis induced by a variety of triggers both in vitro and in vivo. Here we describe the generation and characterization of mice with the targeted deletion of NAIP1. We demonstrate that the NAIP1-deleted mice develop normally. However, the survival of pyramidal neurons in the hippocampus after kainic acid-induced limbic seizures is greatly reduced in the NAIP1 knock-out animals. Thus, although NAIP1 is not necessary for normal development of murine central nervous system, the endogenous NAIP1 is required for neuronal survival in pathological conditions.
AD: Solange Gauthier Karsh Molecular Genetics Laboratory, Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute, Ottawa, ON Canada K1H 8L1.
TA: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A
JT: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
SO: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2000 Feb 29;97(5):2286-90. doi: 10.1073/pnas.040469797.
